content.raw:
Keep in mind that for HAPTIX, the requester is going to be waiting for this function. I don't think we should block the client during 1 second here (worst case). 

I guess you want to make sure that there SDF was correct and the model was inserted. Can we make the wait time smaller maybe?
content.html:
Keep in mind that for HAPTIX, the requester is going to be waiting for this function. I don't think we should block the client during 1 second here (worst case).

I guess you want to make sure that there SDF was correct and the model was inserted. Can we make the wait time smaller maybe?

content.raw: sure, what do you think is a decent wait time?
content.html: sure, what do you think is a decent wait time?

content.raw: physics loop runs at 1000Hz, so how about 1ms?
content.html: physics loop runs at 1000Hz, so how about 1ms?

content.raw:
I changed the sleep time on my desktop and I thought it was working if the maximum timeout was around 100ms, but I had some tricky problems with timeouts running the `sim_api_client` test on my laptop...

Therefore I `AddModel` so that the actual insert model call is put in the `WorldUpdate` callback and a "fake" model object is returned to the user. There's no more wait. It seemed like a cop out at first, and we lose the ability to properly notify the user if the model did not appear in the world, but I think it's much safer not to wait in an ignition transport callback. 0d1fe26
content.html:
I changed the sleep time on my desktop and I thought it was working if the maximum timeout was around 100ms, but I had some tricky problems with timeouts running the sim_api_client test on my laptop...

Therefore I AddModel so that the actual insert model call is put in the WorldUpdate callback and a "fake" model object is returned to the user. There's no more wait. It seemed like a cop out at first, and we lose the ability to properly notify the user if the model did not appear in the world, but I think it's much safer not to wait in an ignition transport callback. 0d1fe26

content.raw: why add 2 here?
content.html: why add 2 here?

content.raw: Because we are averaging over the ambient and diffuse vectors for each visual. If there are `n` visuals in the link and `m` links, there will be `2nm` vectors to average over. Thus we add two to `numVis` per every visual because we've added the ambient and diffuse color vectors. The variable name is a bit misleading, I can add a comment or change the variable name.
content.html: Because we are averaging over the ambient and diffuse vectors for each visual. If there are n visuals in the link and m links, there will be 2nm vectors to average over. Thus we add two to numVis per every visual because we've added the ambient and diffuse color vectors. The variable name is a bit misleading, I can add a comment or change the variable name.

content.raw: `_rep` for reply? :)
content.html: _rep for reply? :)

content.raw: how is `_service` used?
content.html: how is _service used?

content.raw: In ignition transport all the callbacks include the `service` or `topic` associated to the request/message. You can advertise two different services ("/service1", "/service2") and use the same callback to handle the requests. In this scenario, the `_service` parameter can be used to check if the client is requesting a service on "/service1" or "/service2".
content.html: In ignition transport all the callbacks include the service or topic associated to the request/message. You can advertise two different services ("/service1", "/service2") and use the same callback to handle the requests. In this scenario, the _service parameter can be used to check if the client is requesting a service on "/service1" or "/service2".

content.raw: a little confusing that `HaptixModelTransformCallback`'s  `_req` a `hxString` and `HaptixSetModelTransformCallback`'s `_req` a `hxParam`?  Should we make `_rep` `hxTransform` too?
content.html: a little confusing that HaptixModelTransformCallback's _req a hxString and HaptixSetModelTransformCallback's _req a hxParam? Should we make _rep hxTransform too?

content.raw: `hxParam` is a union-like protobuf message that Carlos designed so that the haptix-related ignition transport callbacks can take multiple objects as input. The request for `ModelTransform` is an `hxString` because the request is represented as the name of the model which we are getting the transform for. The request for `SetModelTransform` is an `hxParam` because `SetModelTransform` takes two inputs: the name of the model to set the transform of and the transform to set. I am not going to change the function signatures of these callbacks because they are set in the API.
content.html: hxParam is a union-like protobuf message that Carlos designed so that the haptix-related ignition transport callbacks can take multiple objects as input. The request for ModelTransform is an hxString because the request is represented as the name of the model which we are getting the transform for. The request for SetModelTransform is an hxParam because SetModelTransform takes two inputs: the name of the model to set the transform of and the transform to set. I am not going to change the function signatures of these callbacks because they are set in the API.

content.raw:
Don't you need to increment `iter` here?  E.g.,

    iter = this->wrenchDurations.erase(iter);
content.html:
Don't you need to increment iter here? E.g.,

iter = this->wrenchDurations.erase(iter);

content.raw:
This is a little tricky. The for loop boundaries in 279 and 280 actually doesn't increment `iter` on each loop iteration:

```
  for (auto iter = this->wrenchDurations.begin();
       iter != this->wrenchDurations.end();)
```

Then on line 296, iter increments if we're in the case where we **don't** erase an entry in the vector.

In the case where we **do** erase, we don't increment iter, so we access the next entry in the vector (which is now at the spot we had erased).

I can change this to be more readable, though. I have no idea why I wrote it like this in the first place.
content.html:
This is a little tricky. The for loop boundaries in 279 and 280 actually doesn't increment iter on each loop iteration:

  for (auto iter = this->wrenchDurations.begin();
       iter != this->wrenchDurations.end();)

Then on line 296, iter increments if we're in the case where we don't erase an entry in the vector.

In the case where we do erase, we don't increment iter, so we access the next entry in the vector (which is now at the spot we had erased).

I can change this to be more readable, though. I have no idea why I wrote it like this in the first place.

content.raw:
In 1466404, I fixed `AddModel` by increasing the timeout to 200 ms max.

I also addressed concerns raised by @scpeters and @hsu by queuing functions that should happen in the physics thread and executing them in `OnWorldUpdate`. Inspired by the lesson @dirk-thomas gave this morning, I implemented this by using [C++11 lambdas and capture lists](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/lambda) in various callbacks that set world, model, or link states.  The same effect could be accomplished by using `boost::bind` or `std::bind`, but I found that using lambda was far more concise and readable (once you get used to the syntax). I also had to tweak the tests by calling `World::Step` after each modified call so that the subsequent World update could execute the queued function.

After this change, all tests pass except for `SetModelLinkState`, which gives unexpected values. I will investigate this further (unless @scpeters reviews it first).
content.html:
In 1466404, I fixed AddModel by increasing the timeout to 200 ms max.

I also addressed concerns raised by @scpeters and @hsu by queuing functions that should happen in the physics thread and executing them in OnWorldUpdate. Inspired by the lesson @dirk-thomas gave this morning, I implemented this by using C++11 lambdas and capture lists in various callbacks that set world, model, or link states. The same effect could be accomplished by using boost::bind or std::bind, but I found that using lambda was far more concise and readable (once you get used to the syntax). I also had to tweak the tests by calling World::Step after each modified call so that the subsequent World update could execute the queued function.

After this change, all tests pass except for SetModelLinkState, which gives unexpected values. I will investigate this further (unless @scpeters reviews it first).

content.raw: `SetModelLinkState` and `hxs_set_model_link_state` are being removed from the sim API because Gazebo's behavior for setting the state of individual links is buggy.
content.html: SetModelLinkState and hxs_set_model_link_state are being removed from the sim API because Gazebo's behavior for setting the state of individual links is buggy.

content.raw:
That's not a safe operation.  Consider the case where `iter` points to the beginning of the vector.  Then `erase(iter)` will return an iterator pointing to the beginning of the vector (the new location of the element that previously followed the element that was erased).  Subtracting 1 from the beginning of the vector will, I expect, produce undefined results.

Instead, I would stick with the earlier construction, where you don't increment in the `for`, but rather only increment in the case where you don't erase, and in the other case, assign from the result of the `erase()` call.
content.html:
That's not a safe operation. Consider the case where iter points to the beginning of the vector. Then erase(iter) will return an iterator pointing to the beginning of the vector (the new location of the element that previously followed the element that was erased). Subtracting 1 from the beginning of the vector will, I expect, produce undefined results.

Instead, I would stick with the earlier construction, where you don't increment in the for, but rather only increment in the case where you don't erase, and in the other case, assign from the result of the erase() call.
775265a

content.raw:
Sorry to keep picking at this, but you still need to update the value of `iter`.  Otherwise, after erasing one, you'll come back through the loop and try to dereference it.  I suggest that you assign to it the return value from `erase()`, which will be the [new location of the element that previously followed the element that you erased](http://www.cplusplus.com/reference/vector/vector/erase/), like so:

~~~
iter = this->wrenchDurations.erase(iter);
~~~
content.html:
Sorry to keep picking at this, but you still need to update the value of iter. Otherwise, after erasing one, you'll come back through the loop and try to dereference it. I suggest that you assign to it the return value from erase(), which will be the new location of the element that previously followed the element that you erased, like so:

iter = this->wrenchDurations.erase(iter);

content.raw: I'm trying to write a test case that will fail with the wrong erase semantics before resolving this.
content.html: I'm trying to write a test case that will fail with the wrong erase semantics before resolving this.

content.raw:
The test case I used was the MultipleForces test case in the sim_api test. It adds 6 identical forces, three with a duration of 1 second and three with a duration of 2 seconds. The behavior of wrenchDurations should thus be: push 6 forces onto the stack, erase 3 forces 1 second later, erase 3 more forces 2 seconds later. The test verifies that it receives the correct forces for the next 3 seconds (full force, half force, then no force).

I didn't see any difference between assigning the iter to the return value of `erase` vs. not. I think this is because when `erase` is called, the vector container moves all the elements up to fill the place of the erased item, and when `erase` is called on the last element, the for loop exits before we dereference the vector `end`.

Still, I'll change it to be safe.
	
5c2902b
 
4212418
content.html:
The test case I used was the MultipleForces test case in the sim_api test. It adds 6 identical forces, three with a duration of 1 second and three with a duration of 2 seconds. The behavior of wrenchDurations should thus be: push 6 forces onto the stack, erase 3 forces 1 second later, erase 3 more forces 2 seconds later. The test verifies that it receives the correct forces for the next 3 seconds (full force, half force, then no force).

I didn't see any difference between assigning the iter to the return value of erase vs. not. I think this is because when erase is called, the vector container moves all the elements up to fill the place of the erased item, and when erase is called on the last element, the for loop exits before we dereference the vector end.

Still, I'll change it to be safe.

5c2902b

4212418

content.raw:
Another idea: You could replace your `for` loop with two steps:

* `std::remove_if()` with a lambda function where you check if it's time to remove the impulse from `this->wrenchDurations` (the condition of your `if` right now).
* Apply the force/torque through all the elements of `this->wrenchDurations`.

Ref: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erase%E2%80%93remove_idiom
content.html:
Another idea: You could replace your for loop with two steps:

  • std::remove_if() with a lambda function where you check if it's time to remove the impulse from this->wrenchDurations (the condition of your if right now).
  • Apply the force/torque through all the elements of this->wrenchDurations.

Ref: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erase%E2%80%93remove_idiom

content.raw: Sounds good. I agree with your reasoning for why it works now without the assignment.  But then it probably won't work if you were to change the container to a `list`, so good to be explicit about the iterator handling.
content.html: Sounds good. I agree with your reasoning for why it works now without the assignment. But then it probably won't work if you were to change the container to a list, so good to be explicit about the iterator handling.

Everything works as expected. We need to update documentation to specify clearly that

  * `HaptixModelTransformCallback`, `HaptixSetModelTransformCallback` operates on the Model frame, or more specifically the canonical link frame.  While
  * `HaptixAngularVelocityCallback`, `HaptixSetAngularVelocityCallback`, `HaptixLinearVelocityCallback`, `HaptixSetLinearVelocityCallback` operates on individual link's CG frame.
content.html:
Everything works as expected. We need to update documentation to specify clearly that

  • HaptixModelTransformCallback, HaptixSetModelTransformCallback operates on the Model frame, or more specifically the canonical link frame. While
  • HaptixAngularVelocityCallback, HaptixSetAngularVelocityCallback, HaptixLinearVelocityCallback, HaptixSetLinearVelocityCallback operates on individual link's CG frame.

content.raw: Not needed.

content.raw: `_in` should be `const`.
content.html: _in should be const.

content.raw: I think that `worldControlPlugin` shouldn't know anything about the C types declared in `haptix_sim.h`. The interface between this plugin and the C client is communication via protobuf messages. All the conversion functions should only handle Gazebo types and protobuf messages. You should be able to remove all the conversion functions with hxsXXX types.
content.html: I think that worldControlPlugin shouldn't know anything about the C types declared in haptix_sim.h. The interface between this plugin and the C client is communication via protobuf messages. All the conversion functions should only handle Gazebo types and protobuf messages. You should be able to remove all the conversion functions with hxsXXX types.
